nyd with a Register of the same, in his own hand writing as being 
desirous the Gentlemen of the Society, should without trouble be enabled 
to examin many of these objects, on which he had made his most consi 
 derable discoverys.
Several of these objects yet remain before the Microscopes, tho 
the greater number are broken off, which was probably done by the sha 
king of the boxes in the carriage. I have nevertheless added <s>by the 
assistance of <u>M<sup>r<\sup> Lobman<\u><\s> a translation of the Register, as it may 
serve to give a juster Idea of what <u>M<sup>r<\sup>Lewenhoeck<\u> designd by this 
legacy, and also be of use , by putting any curious observer in mind,
of a number of minute subjects that may in a particular manner 
deserve his attention.
The 13 Cases above mentioned are numberd from 15 to 27 in 
clusively, corresponding to which is the Register of the objects, two to 
every <s>box<\s> Case as follows.
No. 15. Globules of Blood, from which its Redness proceeds.
A thin slice of wood of the Lime tree, where the vessels 
conveying the sap are cut transeversely.
No. 16.
The Eyes of a Gnat.
No. 17. A crooked hair to which adheres a Ring worm, with a 
piece of the Cuticle.
A small hair from the hand by which it appears those 
hairs are not round.
No. 18. Flesh of the Codfish (<u>Cabeliaew<\u>) shewing how the Fibres 
lie oblique to the membranes.
An Embrio of Cochineal, taken from the Egg, in which 
the limbs and horns are conspicuous.
No. 19. Small pipes which compose the Elephants tooth.
Part of the Chrystaline humor from the eye of a 
Whale.
